There are four types of GP services, categorized into Levels A, B, C, and D.
Level A service is for straightforward issues requiring a short patient history and limited examination. It typically involves a brief consultation and basic management.
Level B service includes consultations lasting less than 20 minutes and can involve various clinical activities such as history-taking, examination, investigations, and management plans.
Level C service involves consultations lasting at least 20 minutes and includes detailed history-taking, thorough examination, necessary investigations, and comprehensive management plans.
Level D service is for consultations lasting at least 40 minutes and includes extensive history-taking, comprehensive examination, thorough investigations, and detailed management plans.

A1: For Level A service, the fee is $17.50 per attendance.
A2: For Level B service (less than 20 minutes), the fee is $38.20 per attendance.
A3: For Level C service (at least 20 minutes), the fee is $73.95 per attendance.
A4: For Level D service (at least 40 minutes), the fee is $108.85 per attendance.

A1: For Level A service, the cap is $52.50.
A2: For Level B service (less than 20 minutes), the cap is $114.60.
A3: For Level C service (at least 20 minutes), the cap is $221.85.
A4: For Level D service (at least 40 minutes), the cap is $326.55.

For Level D service, the fee is $108.85 per attendance.
Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) helps you pay for hospital and medical services which you may need while studying in Australia.

As an overseas student, it is a requirement of your overseas student visa that you have OSHC when you apply for your visa and then keep it for the entire duration of your stay in Australia under the student visa.
They will not be covered under your singles policy. You should take out an OSHC family policy to cover your spouse or de-facto partner or any child or step child who is unmarried and under the age of 18. We also have Extras cover for families
Overseas Student Health Cover or OSHC Australia, is specifically designed for international students to help them cover their hospital and medical bills which may occur during their stay in Australia
OSHC Australia stands for Overseas Student Health Cover. It is mandatory for all international students in Australia.
It is compulsory for international students to buy OSHC Australia for the duration of their stay in the country.
Overseas Student Health Cover is health cover for overseas/international students. ItÕs part of Visa requirement 500 allowing you to study in Australia.

Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) is health insurance that gives you access to a range of medical services during your time as a student in Australia. OSHC is a mandatory requirement of every international student wishing to travel to and study in Australia.

You need to purchase an OSHC policy to be eligible for a student visa, and the policy needs to cover you for the full duration of your expected time in Australia. When you purchase an OSHC policy with Bupa, you’ll instantly receive a verification letter to submit with your visa application.
A Refund for your OSHC in Australia will depend on your provider. Each provider has different terms and conditions regarding their refund policy.
OSHC Australia helps student visa holders cover their medical and hospital expenses for their time in Australia.

It is best advised to not enter the country before your OSHC in Australia starts. It is a mandatory requirement for international students thus, you must have it in your hand before or on the date of arrival in Australia.
You can contact your OSHC Australia provider for options available to change or renew your insurance cover.
Yes, you can transfer to another policy. Be aware that some of the policy conditions may be different. Your previous policy duration will count towards any relevant waiting periods on your new cover.

Of course! Your previous provider will give you a clearance certificate. We’ll use this to waive any relevant waiting periods you’ve already served on your previous policy (if it’s within 60 days of your previous cover’s end date).

You can transfer your cover to Medibank from any other Australian OSHC insurer. Your period of membership will count towards any waiting periods you may need to serve with Medibank OSHC.
If your cover with your last insurer has lapsed or expired, other conditions apply. For more information, contact us
Yes! As an international student in Australia, you must have Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC Australia) for the time of your study in the country.

Yes.  As an international student in Australia, you will be required to have an Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) policy for the entire duration of your student visa. International students, and their dependents (for example, spouses and children under 18 years old), must obtain OSHC. You will need to show proof that you have an OSHC policy when you apply for your student visa.
If you are a citizen of either Norway, Sweden or Belgium you may be exempt from having to purchase an OSHC policy.

You need to purchase Overseas Student Health Cover before you can apply for a student visa. This means you need to pay for OSHC upfront, but your cover wonÕt actually commence until the day you arrive in Australia.

As an overseas student, it is a requirement of your overseas student visa that you have OSHC when you apply for your visa and then keep it for the entire duration of your stay in Australia under the student visa.

The Australian Healthcare System can be broken up into two parts: 

The public healthcare system known as Medicare is only available to Australian permanent residents and reciprocal card holders. 
The private health system which is supported by Private Health Insurers (including CBHS International and Overseas cover) will cover you for both emergency and non-emergency health issues, including things like treatment in a private hospital, the cost of an ambulance and other medical or ancillary services. 
There are three reasons why you should take out student cover (OSHC):

It is a requirement for Overseas students while they study in Australia.
OSHC keeps you protected against the costs of medical treatment if you get sick or have an accident. Some treatments can cost thousands of dollars!
Your cover will help lessen the impact of costs on the Australian health system. This helps our country continue to sustainably welcome international students.

The major providers of OSHC Australia are BUPA, NIB, AHM, Allianz Care, and Medibank. They are all approved providers for providing OSHC to overseas students in Australia. All major providers are leading providers however, the best OSHC in Australia for you will be the one that suits your needs and fits your budget.

All major providers are leading providers however, the best OSHC in Australia for you will be the one that suits your needs and fits your budget.

The cost of OSHC Australia will depend on the type of coverage you require and the provider you are buying it from. You can contact your OSHC provider to know the best deal on your OSHC.
Fees for OSHC Australia will depend on the cover type and provider you are buying your OSHC from.

Coverage for family OSHC varies based on the type of policy you purchase. The family usually covers the expense of emergency ambulance services, medical expenses, certain prescription medicines, and more.

They will not be covered under your singles policy. You should take out an OSHC family policy to cover your spouse or de-facto partner or any child or step child who is unmarried and under the age of 18. We also have Extras cover for families

You can purchase Overseas Student Health Cover for singles, single parents, couples, and families – so if you have any dependants living with you in Australia, they can be covered by the same policy.

However, if your family member has their own student visa, or if they’re a member of your extended family, they’ll need to purchase their own health insurance. If your family member is working in or visiting Australia, they might be eligible for our Overseas Visitors Cover instead.
Single parent OSHC in Australia covers the parent with n number of children. You can get coverage for hospital and medical bills, emergency ambulance services, prescription medications, and more.

You can buy OSHC from these OSHC Providers such as BUPA, NIB, AHM, Allianz Care, and Medibank. They are all provided the website and agents to assit you. However, the price and benefit are slighty different. The best OSHC for you will be the one that suits your needs and fits your budget.

As part of your student visa application process, your dedicated education agents will facilitate the purchase of your OSHC with your preferred insurer.Ê The education agent will make sure that the cover that you purchase is correct and compliant with the student visa requirements to ensure that your student visa is granted without any unnecessary delay.

You need to purchase Overseas Student Health Cover before you can apply for a student visa. This means you need to pay for OSHC upfront, but your cover won’t actually commence until the day you arrive in Australia.

You can buy Medibank Essentials OSHC directly online.
Purchase of the Medibank Comprehensive OSHC policy however is only available through selected universities and schools. Check with your institution to see if you can access this cover.

When you buy your OSHC online, you become a member from the date of your arrival in Australia. However, if you don’t pay your OSHC premium before your date of arrival, your commencement date will be the date your OSHC premium is first paid.
If you purchase your OSHC while you are already in Australia, it will start on the day you join.

Different policies can create complications as a single policy is only meant for the person who is the primary visa holder. If a dependent is buying OSHC, he is giving wrong information and portraying himself as a primary visa holder. Therefore, it is advisable that a couple must have couple OSHC in Australia.

No. Your insurer will require that you purchase your entire OSHC policy upfront. You need to purchase a policy that covers the entire period of your student visa so that you can provide the DHA with a valid OSHC certificate when you lodge your student visa application.
In the unlikely event, you needed to leave Australia before completing your studies the insurer would refund the remaining portion of your OSHC policy from the date that you depart Australia.

You will need to hold a valid OSHC policy from the date that your student visa is granted. This may require that your policy begins before you travel to Australia to commence your course.
If you are overseas when you purchase your insurance policy and pay, the insurer will ask you to nominate a date of arrival. This date will be the date that your policy will begin. If your arrival date changes or is delayed you will be able to ask your insurer to change the start date of your policy.
If you are already in Australia with a student visa and are changing insurance providers, then your start date of the policy will be the day after your current OSHC policy expires.
If you are in Australia with another visa type such as a visitor visa or work and holiday then the start date of your policy should be the date that you lodge your student visa application.

As an international student, you must make sure that your OSHC does not expire while you are in Australia. If your OSHC policy expires you will breach your student visa conditions and risk having your student visa cancelled by the Department of Home Affairs (DHA).
Your Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) must cover the entire duration of your student visa. The last day of your student visa will depend on the duration of your course and on the time of the year that your course will finish. If your course is less than ten months your visa will usually expire one month after the course finishes. If it is more than ten months it may expire either 2 months later or on 15 March the following year.
No, your OSHC will only cover you for medical and hospital treatments while you are in Australia. If you take a trip outside Australia you should obtain additional travel insurance for these trips.
OSHC only covers you while you are in Australia. If you travel outside of Australia youÕll need to take out Travel Insurance Ð offers ÒCover-MoreÓ
No. Your overseas student or visitors health cover can only commence once you have arrived in Australia.

Yes. If you are planning to travel to study in Australia with your immediate family (i.e spouse or children) they will also need to be covered by an OSHC policy. To do this you will need to purchase a Dual Family or Multiple Family OSHC policy that covers every person that will be included in the student visa application.
Any adult dependents must be included in your OSHC policy. If you purchase an additional single OSHC policy for an adult dependant instead of a couples policy and your dependant needs to make a claim on the additional policy the insurer may refuse to cover your dependant on the basis that your dependant is not a primary visa applicant, enrolled in an Australian course and that you should have taken out a couples policy.

As a student visa holder, you need an active OSHC policy for the full duration of your stay in Australia Ð not just the length of your course.

Your cover start date should be the same day you plan to arrive in Australia. If you donÕt know your exact arrival date, select the date 28 days before your course commences.

The Department of Home Affairs provides guidance on the length of student visas, and these timeframes can be used to calculate how long youÕll need OSHC for. As a rough guide:

If your course is 10 months or less, youÕll need cover for 1 month longer than your course.
If your course is more than 10 months, and finishes between January and October, youÕll need cover for 2 months longer than your course.
If your course is more than 10 months, and finishes in November or December, youÕll need cover until 15 March the following year.

ItÕs important that you have an active OSHC policy during your time in Australia. If your cover expires, it may be a breach of your visa conditions, which could affect your ability to extend your visa or apply for permanent residency.

An expired policy also means you wonÕt be covered for any hospital or medical services. These could be very expensive if you get sick or injured.

The Department of Immigration & Boarder ProtectionÊrequires holders of a student visa to maintain OSHC for their entire stay in Australia. If you allow your cover to lapse, you will be in breach of your visa conditions. YouÕll also need to renew your OSHC and have to back-pay for any period that you were not covered by OSHC. In addition, you are not entitled to receive benefits for periods when you were not covered by OSHC even if you re-activate your policy and backdate your payments for that period. This may also result in you having to pay very significant hospital, medical or other costs yourself.

It’s important that you have an active OSHC policy during your time in Australia. If your cover expires, it may be a breach of your visa conditions, which could affect your ability to extend your visa or apply for permanent residency.
An expired policy also means you won’t be covered for any hospital or medical services. These could be very expensive if you get sick or injured.
If you need to extend or modify your cover, get in touch today.

If your cover lapses and you wish to reopen your membership, you will need to pay:

The value of the premiums that are outstanding for the lapsed period; and
A premium payment advancing the membership date to the expiry date of your student visa (i.e. visa length health cover).

Remember that you need to maintain your OSHC cover to fulfil the requirements of your student visa.
For further information, please contact us

If you’re staying in Australia on another visa after your student visa expires, you’re no longer able to be covered by OSHC. However, Medibank has a range of health covers which will help keep you protected should any unforseen medical circumstances arise.
If you take out another Medibank hospital cover within two months of your OSHC expiring, you won’t have to serve any additional waiting periods for benefits to which you were entitled to under your OSHC.
Call Medibank on 134 190 to discuss the best health cover options to suit your needs.

No. Even if youÕre on a break between study periods, you need an active OSHC policy while living in Australia.

Cancelling your cover while youÕre still in Australia may breach your visa conditions. This could prevent you from staying in Australia, extending your visa, or applying for permanent residency.

For Bupa, you can apply to temporarily suspend your policy if youÕre travelling outside of Australia for more than 3 consecutive months. YouÕll need to provide your visa grant letter, as well as your travel documents. If youÕre deemed eligible for a policy suspension, youÕll be paid a pro rata refund amount calculated according to your visa end date.

If your OSHC cover lapses or is cancelled, you will no longer be complying with your visa conditions and your visa can be cancelled. If you have an accident or need any medical treatment while you donÕt have health cover, you will have to pay the full cost of that treatment yourself.

To ensure you're covered if your policy has lapsed, youÕll need to back-pay the premium for the time that you werenÕt covered, as well as for the duration of your policy until your visa expires or you leave Australia.

If you’re on a break between study periods, you need an active OSHC policy while living in Australia. Cancelling your cover while you’re still in Australia may breach your visa conditions. This could prevent you from staying in Australia, extending your visa, or applying for permanent residency.

You can apply to temporarily suspend your policy if you’re travelling outside of Australia for more than 3 consecutive months. You’ll need to provide your visa grant letter, as well as your travel documents. If you’re deemed eligible for a policy suspension, you’ll be paid a pro rata refund amount calculated according to your visa end date.

As requested by Department of Health (DoH) under the OSHC Deed, Medibank will be required to provide the name and contact details of any OSHC member (new or existing) to the Department on Immigration and Border Protection (DIBP) where the student has chosen to cancel their OSHC policy.
Medibank is committed to managing personal information according to our Privacy Policy, as amended from time to time."

Of course! If you have an OSHC policy with another health insurance provider but want to switch to Bupa, get in touch today.

Your previous provider will give you a clearance certificate. WeÕll use this to waive any relevant waiting periods youÕve already served on your previous policy (if itÕs within 60 days of your previous coverÕs end date).

You can purchase Overseas Student Health Cover for singles, single parents, couples, and families Ð so if you have any dependants living with you in Australia, they can be covered by the same policy.

However, if your family member has their own student visa, or if theyÕre a member of your extended family, theyÕll need to purchase their own health insurance.

If your family member is working in or visiting Australia, they might be eligible for BUPA Overseas Visitors Cover instead.
No. Bupa OSHC only provides hospital and medical cover while youÕre in Australia. If youÕre travelling outside of Australia during your visa period, we recommend purchasing separate travel insurance.

You or one of your dependants has a pre-existing condition if the signs or symptoms of the ailment, illness or condition you have (in the opinion of a Medical Practitioner appointed by your provider) existed at any time in the 6 month period before you or your dependant arrived in Australia on a student visa. For pre-existing medical conditions and pregnancy related services including childbirth there is a waiting period of 12 months. That means you wonÕt be covered for these conditions until the waiting period is over. For a pre-existing condition of a psychiatric nature, there is waiting period of 2 months.

A pre-existing condition is an illness or medical condition, the signs or symptoms of which existed at any time in the period of six months before the person became insured under an OSHC or OVHC policy. This is determined by a medical advisor appointed by CBHS International Health and takes into consideration any information provided by the memberÕs Health Care Provider.

Your OSHC provider pays for the following services but please remember it is important that you should contact your provider prior to any major treatments, especially staying in the hospital.Pathology and X-rays: 85% of the MBS Fee for out-of-hospital services or 100% of the MBS Fee for in-hospital services.

Emergency ambulance transport: Your provider covers 100% of the cost of emergency transportation in an ambulance.

Prosthetic devices: Your provider covers the full cost of any No Gap prostheses and the minimum benefit for Gap permitted prostheses. Surgically implanted prostheses could include, for example, stents for coronary arteries, artificial hips/knees or titanium plates/screws for reconstructions & bone breaks.

Important: Waiting periods apply for pre-existing conditions. That is, an ailment, illness or condition which either you or one of your dependants have, the signs or symptoms of which, in the opinion of a Medical Practitioner appointed by your provider, existed at any time in the 6 month period before you or your dependant arrived in Australia. For pre-existing medical conditions and pregnancy related services including childbirth there is a waiting period of 12 months. That means you wonÕt be covered for these conditions until the waiting period is over. For a pre-existing condition of a psychiatric nature, there is a waiting period of 2 months.
Doctors: 100% of the Medicare Benefits Schedule fee (MBS Fee) for General PractitionersÕ standard consultations (doctors may charge above the MBS Fee) and 85% of the MBS Fee for other out-of-hospital services.

Hospitals: Including accommodation, operating theatre, day services, emergency and accident services, outpatient medical and post operative services.

Prescription Medicines: You pay a set amount towards the cost (PBS amount) and your provider pays the rest, up to a maximum of $50 per item to a maximum of $300 for a single membership ($600 family). As an overseas student, you may face significant out of pocket costs if you need treatment with Òhigh costÓ pharmaceuticals, particularly oncology (cancer) treatment.

OSHC policies will cover three scenarios:

Singles cover: cover for just you
Couples cover: cover for you and your spouse or de facto partner
Family cover: cover for you, your spouse or de facto partner, and your children under the age of 18 who are living with you in Australia, and are listed on your student visa
Sole parent cover: cover for you, and your dependant children who are under 18, living with you in Australia and listed on your student visa.
We donÕt cover your extended family members such as your parents, grandparents, aunts, uncles, brothers or sisters.

Direct billing is when you visit your General Practitioner (GP) and your GP charges you the MBS Fee. Some doctors have arrangements with OSHC provider to bill directly for the full MBS amount so you wonÕt have any out-of-pocket expenses. Not all GPs direct bill.

You can purchase more cover to have benefits for a range of other services such as dental services, prescription glasses, physiotherapy and chiropractic. Please remember that this cover doesnÕt satisfy your visa requirement and can only be purchased in addition to OSHC. Some waiting periods will apply.

OSHC covers you for the duration of your student visa. If you plan to stay in Australia after your student visa expires, youÕll need to apply for another visa that is specific to your future needs. VisitÊwww.immi.gov.auÊfor more information. If you obtain a different visa (eg an overseas visitor visa, a working visa) you will need to organise different health insurance, as OSHC can only cover you while you are on a student visa.

Many minor illnesses can be treated with medicine from a pharmacy. However, if youÕre sick your first stop should be a visit to a family doctor (called a GP or General Practitioner) Ð the GP will then advise you on what you need to do next.

In Australia, the family doctor is called a GP (or General Practitioner). Except for in an emergency, the first person you will visit will be the GP Ð and you can find GPs all over the place. Go to the GP for minor medical issues (such as stomach ache, sneezing, coughing, fever, a skin rash, diarrhoea). The GP can provide you with advice and a prescription for medication to treat your illness. The GP can also refer you for an x-ray or blood tests or to a specialist doctor if this is necessary.
In Australia, we call our local doctors General Practitioners or GPs.

In Australia, local doctors are known as general practitioners (GPs). You’ll be able to see any GP with your OSHC membership.

A Bupa-friendly doctor is a GP who has agreed to submit your claim directly to Bupa. This helps reduce or eliminate any payment on the day of your appointment.

OSHC members can also book and attend online GP appointments 24/7 through Blua, with 100% of costs covered.

The pharmacy is a place that sells medicines and other health-related items. Some of these medicines are only available when prescribed by a doctor.
Pharmacist can often give you advice on minor illnesses and give you non-prescription medicines to treat them.

If your doctor gives you a prescription for medicine, the pharmacy is where you need to go to get it.

Pharmacists can give you medicines for some minor illnesses like headache, fever, coughs and sneezes without a prescription.

You can also buy bandages, vitamins and other health-related items at the pharmacy.

Our student cover (OSHC) helps members meet the costs of:

1. Visits to the doctor
2. Out of hospital medical treatment
3. In-hospital medical treatment
4. Emergency ambulance
Some prescription medications (medicines prescribed by your doctor in or out of hospital).
See the OSHC policy page for more information.

A specialist is a medical practitioner who has extra training in a particular aspect of healthcare, such as a dermatologist or cardiac surgeon. In Australia, you need a referral from your doctor to see a specialist.
ItÕs important that you contact your insurance company when you arrive in Australia sothey can activate your cover, update your local contact details and send your membership cards.

Sometimes your doctor will prescribe medicine as part of your treatment. A prescription, which can be digital or paper, outlines which medication/s your doctor would like you to take. Show your prescription at a pharmacy or chemist, and they will supply you with the right medicine. If you're not sure how to use the medicine, ask the pharmacist before you go home.

Sometimes you must wait for a period of time before youÕre able to claim benefits for services under your CBHS International Health cover Ð this is called a waiting period. The following waiting periods apply to our policies:

1. Pre-existing medical conditions: 12 months
2. Pregnancy-related services, including miscarriage and termination: 12 months
3. Treatment for pre-existing conditions relating to hospital psychiatric services: 2 months
4. All other services including GP services, accidents, emergency ambulance transport: no waiting period

Exclusions are services that are not covered under your policy. You can seek services for the exclusions but CBHS International Health will not pay any benefits. Examples of exclusions under our health cover are:

Non-admitted hospital psychiatric services
Assisted reproductive services
Cosmetic surgery
Stem cell, bone marrow and organ transplant
Other services for which a Medicare benefit is not payable.

These are medical services you receive in the emergency department of a hospital, but you have not been formally admitted to hospital.

For example, if you consulted with a hospital doctor, had a blood test or x-ray while you were in the emergency department of a hospital, but had not been formally admitted into hospital, this is known as outpatient services.

The formal hospital admission process usually includes you being given a hospital wristband and allocated a hospital bed in a hospital ward (rather than the emergency department). This only happens when youÕve been assessed and meet certain criteria. If you meet the hospital criteria for admission, it is because your doctor has decided you need to stay in hospital (at least overnight) - or you've had pre-planned day surgery/procedure (such as a colonoscopy) and need to be admitted for inpatient care.

If you have not been formally admitted to hospital for an overnight stay when you went to the Hospital emergency department or attended day surgery, your medical treatment you received is outpatient services.

This is medical treatment you receive once you have been formally admitted to hospital.

The formal hospital admission process usually includes you being given a hospital wristband and allocated a hospital bed in a hospital ward (rather than the emergency department). This only happens when youÕve been assessed and meet certain criteria. If you meet the hospital criteria for admission, it is because your doctor has decided you need to stay in hospital (at least overnight) - or you've had pre-planned day surgery/procedure (such as a colonoscopy) and need to be admitted for inpatient care.

Inpatient services include pre-planned hospital admissions for day surgery or a medical procedure (for example colonoscopy). This is where you have day surgery or a medical procedure done, then later the same day you go home. Day surgery or medical procedures can be considered inpatient medical treatment if you need inpatient care, even if you don't need to stay overnight at the hospital.
Subclass 500 is the only eligible student visa subclass.
Only primary visa holders without a spouse, de facto or dependent child are eligible for single cover.

Who is the primary visa holder?

The primary visa holder is the person who applied for and has been granted an eligible student visa. The primary visa holder will be the member insured and the Policy Holder.

Who is the secondary visa holder?+A35

A secondary visa holder is the spouse, de facto partner, or dependent child of the primary visa holder. A secondary visa holder is not eligible for single cover.

Who is eligible for single cover?

Only primary visa holders without a spouse, de facto or dependent child are eligible for single cover.
A secondary visa holder is the spouse, de facto partner, or dependent child of the primary visa holder. A secondary visa holder is not eligible for single cover.
The primary visa holder is the person who applied for and has been granted an eligible student visa. The primary visa holder will be the member insured and the Policy Holder.

In most cases, your student cover will pay for a portion of your medical costs. In some cases, you may need to pay for the bill first and then claim a refund from us. In other situations, the medical provider will bill us directly for your treatment. Let them know you have cover with us and theyÕll tell you what the process is.

Whenever you are seeking treatment, you should always receive informed financial consent from your treating provider. This will provide you with information on any out-of-pocket expenses in relation to your treatment. 

For medication from the pharmacy, you will need to pay for the medicine and then weÕll refund you for some or all of the costs. Make sure you understand what medication you're covered for as there are limitations to what we can pay. If you aren't sure, call us, and we can tell you.
You must be covered for the full length of your stay in Australia under your student visa.
Yes. You can buy overseas health cover directly from insurance providers online or call them.

Reciprocal Health Care Agreements (RHCAs) vary from country to country, so itÕs important to understand what you are and arenÕt covered for before deciding on health insurance. Even if youÕre entitled to reciprocal benefits, Medicare does not cover you for everything and without health insurance you will need to pay for these services. The list below gives examples of services that are NOT covered under RHCA.

Ambulance
Dental care
Elective treatment
Funerals
Medical evacuation to your home country
Paramedical services, for example blood tests
Treatment and accommodation in private hospitals, or as a private patient in a public hospital
Treatment that is not immediately necessary.

If you are an existing OSHC Standard policy holder, you may change or extend your cover dates, and upgrade your product to an OSHC Essentials policy if you like. There is no requirement to upgrade.

If youÕre an existing OSHC Essentials policy holder you are not able to downgrade your product to OSHC Standard, however you can change or extend your cover dates.

Medibank OSHC may only be purchased by people who are or will be in Australia on the following student visa subclasses:
- Visa subclass 500: Student 
Visa subclass 570: Independent ELICOS Sector 
Visa subclass 571: Schools Sector
Visa subclass 572: Vocational Education and Training Sector 
Visa subclass 573: Higher Education Sector
Visa subclass 574: Postgraduate Research Sector
Visa subclass 575: Non Award Sector
Visa subclass 576: Foreign Affairs or Defences  Visa subclasses are subject to change by the government from time to time.

That depends on the types of services or items included on your cover.
-  2 months* - All included services - except those set out below
6 months - Optical Appliances, Ultra bonus for out of pocket expenses
12 months - Pre-existing conditions. However, the 12 month pre-existing condition waiting period does not apply to hospital or hospital substitute treatment for psychiatric treatment, rehabilitation treatment or palliative care, Obstetrics-related services, Dental Treatment and Major dental services including surgical extractions, Orthodontic treatment, CPAP type devices, Breathing appliances
24 months - Blood glucose monitors
36 months - Hearing aids, Laser eye surgery * If you have an accident after joining us or changing cover and require treatment, we'll waive the 2 month waiting period.

Waiting periods will apply if you're a new member, you're rejoining Medibank after not having health cover for some time, or you're changing to a higher level of cover (either within Medibank or transferring from another registered Australian health fund). If you're changing to a higher level of cover, you'll still be entitled to benefits at the level of your former cover while you're serving any waiting periods on your new cover if:
Those services were included under your old cover; and
You've already served the waiting periods that applied under your old cover. Waiting periods may apply to some of our betterhealth programs.

All health funds have waiting periods. In short, a waiting period is a period of time you need to wait after taking out your cover before you can receive benefits for services or items covered. You’re not able to receive benefits for any items or services you might have obtained while you’re serving a waiting period or before you joined Medibank.

An Inpatient is someone who is formally admitted to a registered hospital (including day surgery) to receive medical care or treatment, or for the purpose of obtaining professional attention. This includes Same-day admissions.Medibank OSHC pays Benefits when a member is treated in a private hospital as an Inpatient and the treatment is Included under the cover (refer to your Cover Summary).']

Services that are provided where a member is not admitted to hospital are called Outpatient services. These include:
- Non-admitted hospital services such as visits to hospital accident and emergency departments or visits to a hospital Outpatient clinic
- Out-of-hospital medical services such as those provided in a doctor’s surgery, specialist’s clinic, or by a general practitioner (GP).

Before going to the hospital, it’s important to ask your doctor(s) and the hospital about any potential out-of-pocket expenses you might incur. This information should be provided in writing before your treatment or hospital admission and is known as ‘informed financial consent’. If you’re admitted in an emergency, there may not be time for the hospital or doctor(s) to seek your informed financial consent. Information about your out-of-pocket expenses should be provided as soon as possible after you receive treatment.

The Benefits we pay towards hospital accommodation will depend on whether the hospital admission is for an Included or Excluded service (refer to your Cover Summary), and the type of hospital you’re admitted to as explained below. Included services – we pay Benefits towards Same-day and overnight hospital accommodation and intensive care. Excluded services – no Benefits are payable.

Hospital accommodation Benefits do not include things such as TV hire, newspapers, parking, and take-home items, e.g., crutches. Medibank will not pay Benefits for these (or similar) items and services. The hospital should discuss any charges with you.

Emergency Treatment means the treatment of any of the following Conditions:
A risk of serious morbidity or mortality and requiring urgent assessment and resuscitation\n- Suspected acute organ or system failure 
An illness or injury where the viability of function of a body part or organ is acutely threatened
A drug overdose, toxic substance, or toxin effect
Psychiatric disturbance whereby the health of the patient or other people is at immediate risk 
Severe pain where the viability or function of a body part or organ is suspected to be acutely threatened
Acute haemorrhaging requiring urgent assessment and treatment, or
A Condition that requires immediate admission to avoid imminent morbidity or mortality.
Medibank OSHC can help pay towards eligible Prescription medicines prescribed by a doctor (GP or specialist).

You will need to pay a set contribution amount (also known as a co-payment) towards the cost of eligible Prescription medicines, before we pay any Benefits.\nIf the charge is higher than the Benefit we pay, the difference will be an out-of-pocket expense. Refer to your Cover Summary for information on the member contribution, maximum benefits per item, and annual limits that apply to your membership.

Benefits are not payable for the following:
For medicines not prescribed by a doctor (GP or specialist) to treat an illness, injury, or Condition
For medicines available without a prescription\n- For contraceptives prescribed for contraceptive use only
For medicines prescribed for Cosmetic purposes
For any over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, or herbal medicines
For any medicine not approved by the TGA (Therapeutic Goods Administration) or listed on the ARTG (Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods) for the purpose for which it has been prescribed,
For any Prescription medicines which fall within a Benefit exclusion.\nIt's important to note that you may have large out-of-pocket expenses if you need treatment that uses high-cost Prescription medicines, such as those used in oncology (cancer treatment).

Medibank has arrangements with most hospitals for Benefits to be paid direct to the hospital on a member’s behalf. This generally means you won't need to submit a separate claim for hospital Benefits.If needed, hospital claims can be submitted via post with a completed claim form or at a Medibank store. Where claims are submitted in-store, we’ll assess them separately (at a later date) and pay Benefits to you or the hospital, as appropriate. If a claim form is sent by post, the claim form (including receipts) can be sent to: Medibank OSHC GPO 2984 Melbourne VIC 3001.

A Medibank OSHC Direct Billing provider is a doctor, specialist, or other medical provider that has an agreement with Medibank to send the bill directly to us. This helps reduce or eliminate the upfront payment you would normally be required to make at the time of your appointment. Depending on the doctor you see, you may on occasion experience an out-of-pocket expense above the Benefit paid by Medibank. Before booking your consultation, check with the Direct Billing provider whether any out-of-pocket expenses may apply. Remember to take your membership card and photo identification. To find a Direct Billing provider visit medibankoshc.com.au/find-provider.\nIt’s important to be aware that our agreements with Direct Billing providers are subject to change without notice. You should confirm prior to receiving treatment whether your provider is part of our Direct Billing network.

Medibank retains all account and receipt documentation for the period required by law. Medibank will, on request, provide a Statement of Benefits which may assist you for taxation purposes if applicable. For online claims, members are required to retain receipts, for the period specified in OMS terms and conditions, for verification purposes.
Claims must be submitted within two years of the date of service or the date the item was purchased.', 'No Benefits will be paid for any claims submitted outside 2 years timeframe.

Where you need an Ambulance and your medical Condition is such that you can’t be transported any other way, we’ll pay towards services provided by a Medibank approved Ambulance provider:
- When Ambulance transportation to a hospital or other approved facility is required to receive immediate professional attention
- When an Ambulance is called to provide immediate professional attention but transport by Ambulance isn’t needed 
When, as an Inpatient, the hospital requires you to be transferred from one hospital to another (excluding non-medically necessary Ambulance transfers between public hospitals), and\n
For transport by air Ambulance, where pre-approval has been obtained from Medibank by the air Ambulance provider.

['Medibank does not pay Benefits for any Ambulance service not described under ‘When are Benefits payable?’. This includes:
- Ambulance services where immediate professional attention is not required (e.g. general patient transportation)
- Any Ambulance transport required after discharge from hospital (e.g. transport from hospital to home)
- Inter-hospital transfers when, as an Inpatient, you’re transferred from one public hospital to another public hospital for non-medically necessary reasons
- Any Ambulance costs that are fully covered by a third-party arrangement, such as an Ambulance subscription or federal/state/territory Ambulance transportation scheme, WorkCover, or the motor vehicle accident authority, and
- Any air Ambulance services that are fully subsidised, such as South Care or LifeFlight.']

As a student visa holder, you need an active OSHC policy for the full duration of your stay in Australia – not just the length of your course.Your cover start date should be the same day you plan to arrive in Australia. If you don’t know your exact arrival date, select the date 28 days before your course commences.

The Department of Home Affairs provides guidance on the length of student visas, and these timeframes can be used to calculate how long you’ll need OSHC for. As a rough guide:
If your course is 10 months or less, you’ll need cover for 1 month longer than your course.
If your course is more than 10 months, and finishes between January and October, you’ll need cover for 2 months longer than your course.
If your course is more than 10 months, and finishes in November or December, you’ll need cover until 15 March the following year.
If your travel or study dates change and you need to modify your OSHC, get in touch.
Bupa OSHC only provides hospital and medical cover while you’re in Australia. If you’re travelling outside of Australia during your visa period, we recommend purchasing separate travel insurance.

Your Bupa OSHC covers you for a range of hospital, medical, pharmacy, and ambulance services during your time as a student in Australia. If you want cover for additional services like dental and optometry, you can add extras cover to your policy after your initial purchase.

myBupa is our online members portal. It lets you manage your cover and update your information at any time. Simply sign in to myBupa, go to your account, then select ‘Update contact details’.If you haven’t created a myBupa account yet, register today.

You need your Bupa OSHC membership card to access health cover at hospitals and clinics.

Your school might give you instructions on how to collect your physical membership card. If not, simply sign in to myBupa, go to ‘Cover’, then ‘Order a membership card’. Make sure you’ve entered your new Australian mailing address in the contact details section.

If you have an Android or iOS smartphone, there’s no need to wait for a physical card. Download the myBupa app for iOS or Android to access your digital membership card today.

The Australian Government has a comprehensive list of medical services and treatments, with recommended prices for each. This is known as the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) fee.

Your OSHC will pay up to 100% of the MBS fee for eligible services, but if your doctor or specialist charges more than the MBS fee, there may be a leftover ‘out-of-pocket’ amount which you’ll need to pay.

A gap payment, also known as an out-of-pocket cost, is the difference between what a health service costs and what your health insurance covers.

For example, if you pay $150 to visit a specialist, and your health insurance covers $100, that leaves a difference of $50. This is the out-of-pocket cost which you’ll need to pay yourself.

Always ask your health provider about the cost of treatment upfront. If you’re visiting a general practitioner (GP), try making an appointment with a Bupa-friendly doctor or booking an online consultation through Blua.
You can also reduce or remove costs with Bupa’s Medical Gap Scheme. If a doctor or hospital uses the Medical Gap Scheme for your treatment, they agree to only charge Bupa members up to a certain amount. These hospitals are also known as Members First or Network hospitals.

OSHC does not cover the cost of interpreters, but we have multilingual consultants at Bupa stores who are happy to help.

For personal health questions, property assistance, and general tax and legal inquiries, you can also call Bupa’s 24/7 Student Advice Line for support in more than 150 languages.
Your policy’s terms and conditions are in the Overseas Student Health Cover Fund Rules.

Fund and policy rules apply. 100% of the cost will only be covered for Blua consults. Members will only be able to book general consultations via Blua. Consultations with specialists cannot be booked via Blua. Members who are under 18 years old may need to attend the consultation with a parent or guardian.
Please get in touch with any questions or feedback on your OSHC experience.

The fastest way to lodge a claim is through myBupa.  Simply sign in, go to ‘Make a claim’, and fill out the online form.

You can also claim: with the myBupa app, by visiting a Bupa store in person, through your On-Campus Consultant (if available), or by filling out a claim form (PDF, 865KB) and posting it to us.

Bupa’s general communications are normally sent to the main policyholder, but claims information is treated differently. Claims information might include the amount of money we’ve paid, and tax statements. We understand this can be sensitive information.
Every individual listed on a health insurance policy over the age of 15 can choose their own communication preferences, meaning they can choose whether we send their claims information directly to them or the main policyholder. These settings can be changed in myBupa.
Bupa handles customer data in accordance with our privacy policy.

Sign in to myBupa to view your full claims history. If you don’t have a myBupa account yet, register today.

Your claims history is also available through the myBupa app.

An emergency is a serious illness or injury that poses an immediate risk to your life or long-term wellbeing. In an emergency, you should call 000 (triple zero). They will send an ambulance to take you to hospital if required.

A non-emergency is an illness or injury that needs treatment but isn’t immediately life-threatening. In a non-emergency, try making an appointment with a Bupa-friendly doctor or book an online consultation through Blua.

Read more about what to do if you feel sick, or learn about the difference between doctors and hospitals.

If you arrive in Australia and get sick, but don’t have your membership card yet, you should still go see a doctor. You may have to pay for your treatment upfront then make a claim to be reimbursed later.

If you've got an Android or iOS smartphone, you don’t need to wait for a physical membership card. Download the myBupa app to access your digital membership card today.

Moving to a new country can be as challenging as it is exciting. Get prepared by reading about what to expect when you arrive in Australia.

You can also explore Bupa’s health articles for expert advice on how to take care of your mind and body during difficult times.

If you need treatment, you can choose any general practitioner you like or if it’s an emergency, go to your nearest hospital. If necessary, the doctor will refer you to a specialist for further treatment. Both specialists and general practitioners may order x-rays or pathology tests.
If you require admission to a hospital, you may choose to be admitted to either a public hospital as a private patient, or a private hospital."

A specialist is a medical practitioner who is highly skilled in a specific area, like psychiatrists or dermatologists.

Your GP might send you to a specialist if they think specific expertise is needed to diagnose or treat your health condition. To see a specialist you’ll need a referral from your GP.

In Australia, a pharmacy is often called a ‘chemist’. This is where you go if you need medication.

Some medications require you to see a doctor and get a prescription (or ‘script’). Other common medications can be bought ‘over-the-counter’, meaning you don’t need to see a doctor before purchasing them.

Your OSHC policy helps to pay for a range of prescribed medication (within per person and yearly limits) including: medicines prescribed to you as an outpatient from a hospital, medicines prescribed to you by a doctor or specialist, and medicines listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme (PBS) Schedule.

Some exclusions apply. It’s always best to get in touch with us to check whether the medication you’ve been prescribed is covered by your policy.

Selected prescription contraception items are generally covered by OSHC (up to per person and yearly limits).

Get in touch to check whether the medication you’ve been prescribed is covered.

As a general rule, if a prescribed medication is listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) schedule, and is covered by Medicare for residents and citizens, then your OSHC will help pay for it (up to per person and yearly limits). This includes PrEP and PEP.

Make an appointment with a Bupa-friendly doctor or book an online health consultation through Blua to discuss a prescription. PEP is also available from the emergency departments of most Australian public hospitals and sexual health clinics.

Get in touch for further support, or to check whether a medication you’ve been prescribed is covered by your OSHC.

For sexual health, HIV, and STI tests, schedule an appointment with your closest Bupa-friendly doctor.

Ask for a quote before your appointment to calculate any out-of-pocket costs, or get in touch to check whether a test or procedure will be covered by your OSHC.

Pregnancy and birth are covered by OSHC, but a 12-month waiting period applies for all pregnancy-related conditions. Assisted Reproductive Services are not covered by OSHC.

What you’re covered for will depend on whether you’re admitted to hospital (inpatient) or treated out of hospital (outpatient).

As an inpatient, Bupa OSHC will help cover hospital and medical costs for pregnancy and birth, including: accommodation for overnight or same-day stays, operating theatre, intensive care and labour ward fees, pharmaceuticals approved by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS), provided as part of your treatment, fees charged by doctors, surgeons, anaesthetists or other specialists, most diagnostic tests (recognised by Medicare as medically necessary) such as blood tests and x-rays, and a private room, where available and clinically appropriate. Conditions apply. Contact us for more information.


As an outpatient, we’ll pay up to 100% of the Medicare Benefits Scheme (MBS) fee for the cost of medical services provided by doctors or specialists in or out of hospital. These providers may charge more than the MBS, meaning you’ll need to pay the difference. You can always ask for a quote before beginning treatment to check what your out-of-pocket costs might be.

Costs associated with miscarriage and termination of pregnancy are covered by OSHC. What you’re covered for will depend on whether you’re treated out of hospital (outpatient) or admitted to hospital (inpatient).
Waiting periods, fund and policy rules apply.

It is a condition of most student visas to have health insurance for the full duration of that visa. Medibank OSHC is designed for people who are the holder of a student visa or a person who:

is an applicant for a Student Visa ; and
is the holder of a Bridging Visa; and
was, immediately before being granted the Bridging Visa, the holder of a Student Visa.

Unless you are the holder of a valid student visa, you are not eligible to purchase OSHC from us.
The requirement to have OSHC for the entire length of your student visa applies to overseas students who purchased OSHC on or after 1 July 2010. However, there are limited exceptions for students from certain countries:
Norwegian and Swedish students
Norwegian and Swedish students who are covered by health insurance arrangements provided by their Governments do not need to take out OSHC. Any student not eligible for cover provided by their Government must take out an OSHC policy.
Belgian students
Belgian students studying in Australia are covered under the Reciprocal Health Care Agreement with Australia and do not need to take out OSHC. However, Belgian students may wish to take out OSHC for a more comprehensive level of cover.

With Medibank OSHC you can choose:

a single policy that covers the student only
a couple policy that covers the student and their spouse or de facto partner as listed on the student's visa
a family policy that covers the student and their dependants (such as their spouse or de facto partner and any dependant children under 18 years of age) as listed on the student's visa.

Please note we don't cover members of your family such as parents, grandparents, brothers, sisters, uncles or aunts.
Call Medibank on 134 190 to discuss our range of Visitors health insurance.
Yes. If you arrive in Australia earlier or later than the date you gave us when you joined, you need to let us know immediately by contacting us.

For Medibank Essentials OSHC, you can pay your OSHC premium online.
Purchase of the Medibank Comprehensive OSHC policy however is only available through selected universities and schools. Check with your institution to see if you can access this cover.
Renew your Medibank Essentials OSHC membership online now
